March 05, 2016

Maximum Likelihood Estimation, Maximum a Posteriori Estimation and Naive Bayes (part 2)

Maximum a Posteriori Estimation (MAP)

Generally, MAP is a particular extension of MLE where we take in account a biased assumption of data, called prior knowledge. Specifically Bayes’ theorem (or Bayes’ rule) allows us to incorporate prior probability as follows

[latex display=”true”]P(\theta D) = \frac{P(D \theta)P(\theta)}{P(D)}[/latex]

where

  • [latex]P(D|\theta)[/latex] is the likelihood
  • [latex]P(\theta)[/latex] is the prior probability
  • [latex]P(D)[/latex] is the marginal likelihood
  • [latex]P(\theta|D)[/latex] is the posteriori likelihood

    • The principle of MAP is to estimate [latex]\theta[/latex] that maximise the posteriori likelihood [latex]P(\theta)[/latex]. Thus,

    [latex display=”true”]\hat{\theta}_{MAP} = argmax\ \frac{P(D \theta)P(\theta)}{P(D)}[/latex]

    Notice that the denominator [latex]P(D)[/latex] is independent of [latex]\theta[/latex]. Therefore

    [latex display=”true”]P(\theta D) \propto {P(D \theta)P(\theta)}[/latex]
    [latex display=”true”] \Rightarrow \hat{\theta}_{MAP} = argmax\ {P(D \theta)P(\theta)}[/latex]

    By assuming attributes [latex]X_{1}, X_{2}, …, X_{n}[/latex] are independent of each other, we have

    [latex display=”true”]\hat{\theta}_{MAP} = argmax\ P(\theta) \prod_{i=1}^n P(X_i|\theta)[/latex]
